pair.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: an object that is made from two similar parts that are joined together
pair.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: two things of the same type that are used together
pair.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: We have five pairs of free tickets to give away.
She felt as if every pair of eyes in the room was on her.
pair.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: two people who are standing or doing something together, or who have some type of connection with each other
pair.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The pair are looking for sponsorship from local businesses.
pair.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: a male and a female animal that come together in order to breed
pair.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to put people or things into groups of two, or to form groups of two
pair.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: We were each paired with a newcomer to help with training.
pair.translation[1].definitions[0].note_: Pair is usually passive in this meaning, when used as a transitive verb
pair.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: if animals pair, they come together in order to breed
pair.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: if two companies, people, or things are paired, they are put into groups of two because they are connected in some way or will work together
pair.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: When the new products were paired, encouraging customer gains resulted.
Chrysler paired with Hilton Hotels for a promotion giving frequent hotel guests free Chrysler cars.
Any cut in capital gains taxes would be paired with increases in other taxes.
pair.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: if the shares in two companies are paired, they are considered to be shares in one company when they are bought or sold, even though the companies have separate management arrangements
pair.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: The companies are managed separately, but their shares are paired for trading in the market.
